metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: AngularJS Modules
An AngularJS module defines an application.
content.html: An AngularJS module defines an application.

content.text: The module is a container for the different parts of an application.
content.html: The module is a container for the different parts of an application.

content.text: The module is a container for the application controllers.
content.html: The module is a container for the application controllers.

content.text: Controllers always belong to a module.
content.html: Controllers always belong to a module.

content.text: Creating a Module
A module is created by using the AngularJS function angular.module
content.html: A module is created by using the AngularJS function angular.module

content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp">...</div>

<script>

var app = angular.module("myApp", []);

</script>

content.text: The "myApp" parameter refers to an HTML element in which the application will run.
content.html: The "myApp" parameter refers to an HTML element in which the application will run.

content.text: Now you can add controllers, directives, filters, and more, to your AngularJS application.
content.html: Now you can add controllers, directives, filters, and more, to your AngularJS application.

content.text: Adding a Controller
Add a controller to your application, and refer to the controller with the ng-controller directive:
content.html: Add a controller to your application, and refer to the controller with the ng-controller directive:

content.code: {{ firstName + " " + lastName }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">
{{ firstName + " " + lastName }}
</div>

<script>

var app = angular.module("myApp", []);

app.controller("myCtrl", function($scope) {
  $scope.firstName = "John";
  $scope.lastName = "Doe";
});

</script>

content.text: You will learn more about controllers later in this tutorial.
content.html: You will learn more about controllers later in this tutorial.

content.text: Adding a Directive
AngularJS has a set of built-in directives which you can use to add functionality to your application.
content.html: AngularJS has a set of built-in directives which you can use to add functionality to your application.

content.text: For a full reference, visit our AngularJS directive reference .
content.html: For a full reference, visit our AngularJS directive reference.

content.text: In addition you can use the module to add your own directives to your applications:
content.html: In addition you can use the module to add your own directives to your applications:

syntaxHighlighting.text: "I was made in a directive constructor!"

syntax_highlighting.text: "I was made in a directive constructor!"

content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" w3-test-directive></div>

<script>
var app = angular.module("myApp", []);

app.directive("w3TestDirective", function() {
  return {
    template : "I was made in a directive constructor!"
  };
});
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: "I was made in a directive constructor!"

content.text: You will learn more about directives later in this tutorial.
content.html: You will learn more about directives later in this tutorial.

content.text: Modules and Controllers in Files
It is common in AngularJS applications to put the module and the controllers in JavaScript files.
content.html: It is common in AngularJS applications to put the module and the controllers in JavaScript files.

content.text: In this example, "myApp.js" contains an application module definition, while "myCtrl.js" contains the controller:
content.html: In this example, "myApp.js" contains an application module definition, while "myCtrl.js" contains the controller:

content.code: {{ firstName + " " + lastName }}
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.6.9/angular.min.js"></script>
<body>

<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">
{{ firstName + " " + lastName }}
</div>

<script src="myApp.js"></script>
<script src="myCtrl.js"></script>

</body>
</html>

content.text: The [] parameter in the module definition can be used to define dependent modules.
content.html: The [] parameter in the module definition can be used to define dependent modules.

content.text: Without the [] parameter, you are not creating a new module, but retrieving an existing one.
content.html: Without the [] parameter, you are not creating a new module, but retrieving an existing one.

content.text: Functions can Pollute the Global Namespace
Global functions should be avoided in JavaScript. They can easily be overwritten or destroyed by other scripts.
content.html: Global functions should be avoided in JavaScript. They can easily be overwritten or destroyed by other scripts.

content.text: AngularJS modules reduces this problem, by keeping all functions local to the module.
content.html: AngularJS modules reduces this problem, by keeping all functions local to the module.

content.text: When to Load the Library
While it is common in HTML applications to place scripts at the end of the <body> element, it is recommended that you load the AngularJS library either in the <head> or at the start of the <body> .
content.html: While it is common in HTML applications to place scripts at the end of the <body> element, it is recommended that you load the AngularJS library either in the <head> or at the start of the <body>.

content.text: This is because calls to angular.module can only be compiled after the library has been loaded.
content.html: This is because calls to angular.module can only be compiled after the library has been loaded.

content.code: {{ firstName + " " + lastName }}
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.6.9/angular.min.js"></script>

<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">
{{ firstName + " " + lastName }}
</div>

<script>
var app = angular.module("myApp", []);
app.controller("myCtrl", function($scope) {
  $scope.firstName = "John";
  $scope.lastName = "Doe";
});
</script>

</body>
</html>
